The *umuD* gene encodes the autoproteolytic subunit of DNA polymerase V (Pol V), which is part of the error-prone translesion synthesis (TLS) pathway. In *Escherichia coli*, UmuD undergoes RecA-mediated cleavage to form UmuD′, which complexes with UmuC to form Pol V. This polymerase bypasses DNA lesions (e.g., UV-induced damage) during SOS response, enabling replication restart but introducing mutations[1][2]. In cyanobacteria like *Synechocystis* sp. In cyanobacteria, UmuD degradation via the N-end rule pathway maintains low basal levels, preventing untimely mutagenesis and optimizing growth under stress[4].
